Answers: The common cold is a viral infection of your nose and throat (upper respiratory tract). It's usually harmless, although it might not feel that way.
Hypertension, also known as high blood pressure, is a condition in which the blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated.

Questions: What is the function of the heart?
Answers: The heart is a muscle that pumps blood throughout the body, supplying oxygen and nutrients to the tissues and removing carbon dioxide and other wastes.
Insulin is a hormone made by the pancreas that allows your body to use sugar (glucose) from carbohydrates in the food that you eat for energy or to store glucose for future use.
Antibiotics are medicines used to prevent and treat bacterial infections.
Vaccines work by stimulating the body's immune system to protect against infectious diseases.
Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus, which can make breathing difficult.
Diabetes is a chronic condition that affects how your body turns food into energy.
A migraine can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound.
Anemia is a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues.
A vegetarian diet is a diet that does not include meat, fish, and poultry. However, there are variations of the vegetarian diet, some of which allow dairy, eggs, and other animal products.
A virus is a small infectious agent that replicates only inside the living cells of an organism. Viruses can infect all types of life forms.
Vitamin D is a nutrient essential for healthy bones and immune system function. It's produced by the body in response to skin being exposed to sunlight.
A wart is a small, fleshy bump on the skin or mucous membrane caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

Questions: What is a white blood cell?
Answers: White blood cells, also known as leukocytes, are cells of the immune system that protect the body against both infectious diseases and foreign invaders.
An X-ray is a quick, painless test that produces images of the structures inside your body, particularly your bones.
Yoga is a physical, mental, and spiritual practice that originated in ancient India. It often involves meditation, exercise, and breathing techniques.
Zoonosis refers to diseases that can be passed from animals to humans. These can be caused by viruses, bacteria, parasites, and fungi.
An allergen is a typically harmless substance that causes an allergic reaction in some people.
Alopecia refers to hair loss from parts of the head or body. The condition can vary from small, localized areas to complete loss of body hair.
Anemia is a condition in which you don't have enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, leading to fatigue and weakness.
Angioplasty is a surgical procedure to restore blood flow through the artery, usually involving the temporary insertion of a balloon to dilate the artery.
Antiseptic refers to substances that prevent the growth of disease-causing microorganisms. They're used on living tissues and cells to prevent infection.
Anxiety is an emotion characterized by feelings of tension, worried thoughts, and physical changes like increased blood pressure.
Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix, a finger-shaped pouch that projects from your colon on the lower right side of your abdomen. It causes pain and requires immediate treatment.
Arrhythmia refers to an irregular heartbeat - the heart may beat too fast, too slowly, too early, or irregularly.
Arthritis is the inflammation of one or more of your joints, causing pain and stiffness that can worsen with age.
An autoimmune disease is a condition in which your immune system mistakenly attacks your body. The immune system normally guards against germs, but in autoimmune diseases, it attacks healthy cells.

A biopsy is a medical test commonly performed by a surgeon, an interventional radiologist, or an interventional cardiologist involving extraction of sample cells or tissues for examination to determine the presence or extent of a disease.
Blood pressure is the pressure of circulating blood against the walls of blood vessels. Most of this pressure results from the heart pumping blood through the circulatory system.
Bronchitis is an inflammation of the lining of your bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from your lungs. People who have bronchitis often cough up thickened mucus.
A cataract is a clouding of the normally clear lens of your eye. For people who have cataracts, seeing through cloudy lenses is like looking through a frosty or fogged-up window.
Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the initial infection with varicella zoster virus. It typically results in a blister-like rash, itching, tiredness, and fever.
A concussion is a type of traumatic brain injury—or TBI—caused by a bump, blow, or jolt to the head or by a hit to the body that causes the head and brain to move rapidly back and forth.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. It's caused by long-term exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter, most often from cigarette smoke.
Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). It causes inflammation of your digestive tract, which can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition.
Cystic fibrosis is a hereditary disease that affects the lungs and digestive system. The body produces thick and sticky mucus that can clog the lungs and obstruct the pancreas.
Dementia is not a specific disease but is rather a general term for the impaired ability to remember, think, or make decisions that interferes with doing everyday activities.

Dental plaque is a sticky, colorless or pale yellow film that is constantly forming on your teeth. When saliva, food, and fluids combine, plaque - which contains bacteria - forms between your teeth and along the gum line.
Dermatitis is a general term that describes a skin irritation. Dermatitis is a common condition that has many causes and occurs in many forms.
Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). It's characterized by high levels of sugar in the blood.
Dyslexia is a learning disorder that involves difficulty reading due to problems identifying speech sounds and learning how they relate to letters and words.
Eczema is a condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age and tends to be chronic and flare periodically.
Edema is swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in your body's tissues. It commonly affects the legs, ankles, or feet.
Endometriosis is a painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus grows outside your uterus.
Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.
Erectile dysfunction (ED) is the inability to get or keep an erection firm enough to have sexual intercourse.
Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.
Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, the health of which is vital for good vision. This damage is often caused by an abnormally high pressure in your eye.
Gout is a common and complex form of arthritis that can affect anyone. It's characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness in the joints.
Hay fever, also known as allergic rhinitis, is an allergic response to certain allergens, most commonly to pollen from trees, grasses, and weeds.
Hemophilia is a rare disorder in which your blood doesn't clot normally because it lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins.
Hepatitis refers to an inflammation of the liver. It can be caused by several viruses, the most common of which are hepatitis A, B, and C.
Herpes is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus. Infections are categorized based on the part of the body infected.
HIV is a virus that damages the immune system. AIDS is a disease that occurs when the immune system is severely damaged and the body can't fight off infections.
Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, and weight gain.
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common disorder that affects the large intestine, causing cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.
Influenza, or flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can cause mild to severe illness and can lead to hospitalization and death.
Jaundice is a yellow discoloration of the skin and eyes due to high bilirubin levels. It can be a sign of several health problems.
Kidney stones are hard deposits made of minerals and salts that form inside your kidneys and can affect any part of the urinary tract.
Lactose intolerance is a condition in which people have symptoms due to the decreased ability to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products.
Leukemia is a type of cancer of the blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system.
Lupus is a systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs.
Lyme disease is a bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. It can lead to fatigue, fever, body aches, and skin rash.
Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer, which develops in the cells that produce melanin — the pigment that gives your skin its color.
Menopause is the time that marks the end of a woman's menstrual cycles. It's diagnosed after 12 months without a menstrual period.
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord, where the immune system attacks the protective sheath covering nerve fibers.
Osteoporosis is a bone disease that occurs when the body loses too much bone, makes too little bone, or both, making bones weak and prone to breaks.
Parkinson's disease is a progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement, causing tremors, stiffness, and difficulty with balance.
Psoriasis is a skin disorder that causes skin cells to multiply up to 10 times faster than normal, leading to red, flaky, and crusty patches.
Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder that can cause joint pain and damage throughout your body.
Scoliosis is a sideways curvature of the spine that occurs most often during the growth spurt just before puberty.
Tuberculosis (TB) is a potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body.
Ulcers are sores that can develop in different parts of the body, most commonly in the lining of the stomach or the upper part of the small intestine.
Vertigo is a sensation of spinning or dizziness, often accompanied by nausea and sometimes by vomiting, difficulty standing, or walking.
Whooping cough, or pertussis, is a highly contagious respiratory tract infection characterized by a severe hacking cough followed by a high-pitched intake of breath.
Xerostomia, also known as dry mouth, is a condition in which the salivary glands in your mouth don't produce enough saliva.
Yellow fever is a viral infection spread by a particular type of mosquito. It's most prevalent in certain parts of Africa and South America.
Zika virus is a mosquito-borne viral infection that primarily occurs in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, known to cause birth defects in babies.
Adenitis is the inflammation of a gland, often associated with swollen lymph nodes.
Bell's palsy is a sudden, temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, often affecting one side of the face.
Beriberi is a disease caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) affecting the cardiovascular system and the nervous system.
Cardiomyopathy refers to diseases of the heart muscle, making it harder for the heart to pump blood to the rest of the body.
Cellulitis is a common bacterial skin infection, causing redness, swelling, and pain in the affected area.
Diverticulitis is an inflammation or infection of small pouches called diverticula that develop along the walls of the intestines.
Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain, often due to a viral infection.
Fatty liver, or steatosis, is the build-up of excess fat in liver cells, which can lead to liver damage.
Gastritis is an inflammation of the stomach lining, which can be caused by various factors including prolonged use of NSAIDs, infections, or chronic stress.
Hemochromatosis is a disorder where too much iron builds up in the body, leading to liver disease, heart problems, and diabetes.
Ichthyosis is a family of genetic skin disorders characterized by dry, scaling skin that may be thickened or very thin.
Jaundice in newborns, or neonatal jaundice, is a yellow discoloration of a baby's skin and eyes due to high bilirubin levels.
Keratitis is an inflammation of the cornea, the clear front surface of the eye.
Lymphedema is the swelling that generally occurs in one of your arms or legs, often due to the removal or damage to your lymph nodes.
Macular degeneration is an eye disease that can blur the sharp, central vision needed for activities like reading and driving.
Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by overwhelming daytime drowsiness and sudden attacks of sleep.
Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people. It occurs when the protective cartilage on the ends of your bones wears down over time.
Peritonitis is the inflammation of the peritoneum, the thin tissue that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers most of the abdominal organs.
Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a condition where there's an uncontrollable urge to move your legs, usually because of an uncomfortable sensation.
Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin, causing intense itching.
Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears, a common problem affecting about 1 in 5 people.
Uremia is a severe condition that occurs when the kidneys no longer filter and eliminate waste products from the blood.
Vitiligo is a long-term skin condition characterized by patches of the skin losing their pigment.
Wilson's disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs.
Xanthoma is a condition in which fatty growths develop underneath the skin, often associated with high levels of blood lipids.
Yaws is a tropical infection of the skin, bones, and joints caused by the spirochete bacterium Treponema pallidum pertenue.
Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the pharynx and the esophagus, leading to difficulty swallowing and regurgitation.
